thread.title: 5 key facts to know about the SABMiller-InBev merger
thread.title_full: 5 key facts to know about the SABMiller-InBev merger - MarketWatch

author: Sara Sjolin
title: 5 key facts to know about the SABMiller-InBev merger
text:
After weeks of negotiation and months of speculation, beer giants SABMiller PLC and Anheuser-Busch InBev SA on Tuesday said they’ve agreed on the keys terms for a merger.
The tie-up still has to go through a formal bidding process and get regulatory clearances. But if consummated, the deal will create the world’s largest brewer that sells about a third of the world’s beer.
Here are five key facts to know about this mega-beer merger.
1. The price looks to be about $105 billion After rejecting four other proposals, SABMiller’s SAB, +8.93% SBMRY, -0.18% board unanimously agreed to recommend to shareholders InBev’s ABI, +1.98% BUD, -0.35% offer of 44 pounds ($67.67) a share. If all shares were sold at this price, SABMiller would be valued at about £71 billion.
However, InBev also offered a partial-share alternative for 41% of SABMiller’s stock — the chunk owned by the brewer’s two biggest shareholders Altria MO, +1.14% and BevCo. That essentially works out to a cash-and-share combination translating into a price of £39.03 a share.
The partial-share alternative brings the total SABMiller valuation down to £68 billion, or $104.58 billion. InBev had made previous offers at £38, £40, £42.15, and £43.50 per share, but SABMiller rejected them, claiming they undervalued the company.
2. The share price The £44-a-share bid offered to the majority of SABMiller’s shareholders marks a 50% premium to the brewer’s trading level on Sept. 14, the day before media speculation about a potential merger erupted.
SABMiller shares jumped 8.5% to £39.31 on Tuesday in London trade after the takeover agreement, still putting it more than 10% below the offer price.
Shares of InBev rose 1.8% in Brussels, while U.S.-listed shares of the brewer climbed 1.9% in premarket action.
3. Watch out for the world’s largest brewer with 29% market share Ahead of this merger, InBev was already the world’s largest brewer, followed by SABMiller in second place. Now, if this just-announced tie-up goes through, the new company will overwhelmingly take the top spot as the biggest brewer in the world, with a combined market share of 29%, according to estimates from research firm Euromonitor.
